locations.name: Bahen 1F
locations.long_description: You are on the first floor of the Bahen Center. This floor is bustling with students heading to and from their classes. The smell of coffee drifts from a nearby lounge, and you can hear the faint tapping of laptop keyboards. There are elevators to the West and an exit to St. George Street to the East.

locations.name: St. George Street
locations.brief_description: A busy street in the heart of UofT.
locations.long_description: Students rush between buildings, some on bikes, others chatting in groups or looking at their phones. You can see Bahen Center to the West and the massive Robarts Library to the East. The sounds of honking and conversation blend together into the familiar hum of campus life.

locations.name: Bahen 2F
locations.long_description: A quieter study space than the first floor, this area has small clusters of students working on assignments. There are rows of computers available, but many are occupied. A vending machine hums in the corner, offering snacks and drinks to those who need a pick-me-up. There’s a hallway leading North to St. George Street and East to Bahen 3F.

locations.name: Bahen 3F
locations.long_description: The third floor is dedicated to research and collaborative projects. Whiteboards filled with equations and diagrams line the walls. A group of students discuss something excitedly near a table filled with open laptops. The hallway leads West to Bahen 2F, and there is an elevator going down.

locations.name: Robarts Library
locations.long_description: The towering bookshelves are filled with volumes on every subject imaginable. Students sit in study pods, focused on their work, while others browse through the stacks. The air is filled with the faint scent of old books and coffee. A librarian nods at you as they pass by. There is an exit to the West leading back to St. George Street.

locations.name: Convocation Hall
locations.brief_description: A historic building used for ceremonies and lectures.
locations.long_description: Convocation Hall stands proudly, its domed roof a familiar sight for students attending lectures or graduation ceremonies. Inside, the echo of footsteps fills the vast space, and the stage stands ready for the next big event. Rows of seats stretch out in all directions, and you can feel the weight of history in the air. You can go South to Robarts or West to Tim Hortons.

locations.name: Tim Hortons
locations.brief_description: A coffee shop popular among students.
locations.long_description: The line at Tim Hortons is long, as usual, but the aroma of freshly brewed coffee makes the wait worth it. Students huddle around small tables, some frantically reviewing notes while others chat about weekend plans. The baristas work quickly, calling out orders over the hum of conversation. You can exit East back to Convocation Hall or go South to the dormitory.

locations.name: Dormitory
locations.long_description: Your dorm room is a sanctuary of clutter and comfort. Your desk is covered with notes, half-finished assignments, and empty coffee cups. Your lucky UofT mug sits precariously on a pile of textbooks. The bed looks inviting, but there's no time to rest now. Posters and photos decorate the walls, reminding you of late-night study sessions and good times with friends. There’s a door leading North to Tim Hortons.

locations.name: Sidney Smith Hall
locations.brief_description: A bustling academic building with many lecture halls.
locations.long_description: Sidney Smith Hall is always busy, with students rushing to lectures or grabbing a quick snack from the vending machines. Posters for student clubs and events cover the walls.

locations.name: Hart House
locations.brief_description: A cultural center with arts, music, and a quiet reading room.
locations.long_description: Hart House is a peaceful retreat from the academic grind. There's a small theater, a reading room, and a gym where students take a break from their studies.

locations.name: Medical Sciences Building
locations.brief_description: A science building with busy labs and classrooms.
locations.long_description: Students in lab coats rush between floors, carrying textbooks and research papers. The faint smell of chemicals lingers in the air.

locations.name: UofT Bookstore
locations.brief_description: A shop selling textbooks, stationery, and UofT merch.
locations.long_description: Shelves are filled with required course textbooks, notebooks, and university merchandise. A sale on hoodies has attracted a small crowd.

locations.name: King’s College Circle
locations.brief_description: A scenic outdoor space surrounded by historic buildings.
locations.long_description: King’s College Circle offers a break from the city noise, with green lawns and a scenic view of UofT’s historic buildings.

locations.name: Science Research Building
locations.brief_description: A building home to laboratories and research spaces.
locations.long_description: The building is filled with research labs, each buzzing with students conducting experiments. Whiteboards are covered with complex equations.

locations.name: Trinity College
locations.brief_description: One of UofT's historic colleges with a beautiful chapel.
locations.long_description: Trinity College is home to a beautiful chapel and old stone buildings. The quiet atmosphere is perfect for focused study.

locations.name: Victoria College
locations.brief_description: A peaceful academic building with a grassy quad.
locations.long_description: Victoria College is a quiet escape, with a large grassy quad and peaceful study spaces. Students relax between classes on the benches.

items.name: toonie
items.description: A shiny toonie on the ground.

items.name: library_card
items.description: A library card for accessing Robarts.

items.name: coffee
items.description: A hot cup of coffee from Tim Hortons.

items.name: USB_drive
items.description: The USB drive containing your project.

items.name: lucky_mug
items.description: Your lucky UofT mug, essential for submission.
